headline: World Snooker Championship: Barry Hearn more confident of Crucible stay after 'positive' talks with Sheffield City Council | Sky Sports
context: Barry Hearn is a "little more hopeful" that the World Snooker Championship will remain at The Crucible after positive talks with Sheffield City Council.
The Sheffield venue has played host to snooker's biggest tournament since 1997, however its current contract is due to expire in two years.

annotations.paragraph: Uncertainty over its future comes amid supposed interest from both China and Saudi Arabia in hosting the Championship.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about potential competition for hosting the Championship.

annotations.paragraph: "I am quietly pleased," Hearn told Sky Sports News. "I feel they are now more positive when it comes to understanding my position and they have a real passion and desire to keep the World Championship at the venue."
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Hearn about the positive talks with Sheffield City Council.

annotations.paragraph: Hearn warned that the Championship could leave the iconic venue when its contract runs out in 2027.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critical warning about the potential future of the Championship.

annotations.paragraph: "We have to be realistic, money is the most important thing." Hearn said. "It's not over until the fat lady sings but at the moment the fat lady is starving."
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a quote from Hearn emphasizing financial considerations.

annotations.paragraph: Hearn wants the tournament to stay at The Crucible but the Matchroom president, along with many leading players, has become frustrated that the 980-capacity venue is holding back the growth of the event and the sport.
